title: A shopkeeper sold two watches, each $100, and had 10% profit on one and 10% loss on another. What was his common loss or gain percent? - Quora

response.answer_text: Selling price(SP)of watch no1= $100 Selling price(SP) of watch no 2 = $100 PROFIT on watch no1 = 10% ie, $10 profit on $100 cost price(CP) Since, CP + PROFIT = SP 100 + 10 = $110 When SP is $110 , then CP is $100 Therefore, when SP is $100, then CP= (100x100)/110 = 1000/11 So, CP of watch no1 = $1000/11 ………....(1) Now LOSS on watch no2=10% ie, $10 loss on $100 CP Since, CP — LOSS = SP 100 - 10 = $90 When SP is $90 then CP is $100 Therefore, when SP is $100, then CP= (100x100)/90 = $1000/9 So CP of watch no2= $1000/9…………..(2) Now, Total SP of both the watches= 100+100= $200……………(3) & Total CP of both the watches = 1000/11 +1000/9 = $ 20,000/99………….(4) Here, ….(4) is >….(3) ie, CP > SP So, shopkeeper has to incur LOSS CP — SP = LOSS 20,000/99 — 200 = ( 20,000 — 19800)/99 = $200/99 LOSS LOSS% =( LOSS/ CP) x 100 LOSS% = (200/99) ÷ (20,000/99) x100 = (200 x 99) / (99x 20,000) x 100 = 1% ANS 1% LOSS Showing the method in short : CP of watch1 = {(100cp) / (on 110sp)} * 100sp = 10,000/110 = 1,000/11 CP of watch 2 = {(100cp) / (on 90sp)} * 100sp = 10,000/90 = 1,000/9 Total CP = (9thousand + 11thousand)/99 = 20thousand/99 So, loss = (20thousand/99) - 200 = 200/99 So, loss% =( loss/cp) * 100 => (200/99)/ (20thousand/99) * 100 = 1% & The shortest method is: . . . Just apply the formula.. If SP of 1 = SP of 2 & profit% on 1 = Loss % on 2 = x, Then, overall loss% = (x/10)²% This formula can be derived….

Based on the question of only 2 watches sold, one with a profit and one with a loss, I calculate the shopkeeper broke even from the sale of these watches, i.e there is no gain or loss. Below shows the calculation used to come up with the profit/loss figure for this answer Watch A Retail price = $100 Cost price = $90 Margin = $10 Margin % = 10% Watch B Retail price = $100 Cost price = $110 Margin $ = -$10 Margin % = -10% Add both figure together Total Retail price = $200 Cost price = $200 Margin $ = $0 Margin % = 0%
